content:
Is it normal for a context of 48k-50k with outputs of 10k-15k to use up all tokens for a session after only 3-4 outputs? Opus 4.5

I've been using Opus 4.5 and I like it a lot. But I keep running out of session tokens extremely fast. I get 3-4 outputs from the AI and then I'm out of tokens.  

Do this 4 times across 2 days, and I'm out of my whole week's worth of tokens.  

This is on Pro plan.  

This is simply unusable.

author: sokoliem_04019#0

content:
I'm using about 402k tokens a day. So 804k tokens in 2 days... Then claude's weekly limit is hit.

5x plan would probably only just *barely* get through to the end of the week with the *current* pace I'm operating at.

Which is already too slow at around 8 messages a day.

All 5x plan would do is mean that I would be able to do 8 messages *every day* rather than just 16 messages every week.

Sure, a substantial increase but it's nowhere near operationally useful for the sort of context I need the AI to keep track of.

author: jarlyk#0

content:
Gemini can't write the prose I use unfortunately.

Here's an example of what I've been getting from Claude Opus.

> The glass had only moved â€“ perhaps an inch across the wooden table, leaving a faint scratch in the varnish that I traced later with my finger when no one was watching. Such a small thing to damn a boy over. But I had *wanted* it to move â€“ had felt something build in my chest like pressure behind a door, tight and strange and inevitable â€“ and then the glass had slid, and Sister Margaret's face had told me everything I needed to know about what I was.

> St. Clement's Home for Foundlings sat in the grey belt between London proper and the sprawl beyond. A Victorian pile of soot-stained brick, narrow windows that let in more cold than light, hallways that smelled of boiled cabbage and floor wax and the particular staleness of unloved spaces. The building itself seemed tired, as if it had been holding children for too long and had forgotten why it bothered.

> I lived there from as early as I could remember until the December after my sixth birthday. Five years of scratched wooden floors and suspicious glances and Sister Margaret's certainty that I was damned.

> I learned things in those years. How to be quiet. How to watch. How to make myself small enough that the nuns' attention would pass over me like water over stone. The other children learned to avoid me after the glass incident spread through whispered tellings, each repetition adding something new and terrible.

content:
This kind of works as a prompt loop: 

`[insert instructions to do].  Law of laziness: After each action, ask yourself "could i be less lazy?" explain how the answer is yes and then proceed to be less lazy. loop this action until the answer is "no, it's impossible to be less lazy"`

next then no matter what outcome you get, repeatedly send this same message  N times where optimal N might be 10-20

`rejected to due to failure to follow your law of laziness. Articulate the law and proceed to follow it this time`
